What makes something 'true'?
William James, the father of American pragmatism, argued that truth is what works.

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ« William James

  • Year: 1842â€“1910
  • Publications:
    • The Principles of Psychology (1890)
    • The Will to Believe (1897)
    • Pragmatism (1907)
    • A Pluralistic Universe (1909)
  • Contributions:
    • Popularized Pragmatism
    • Introduced the concept of stream of consciousness
    • Helped establish psychology as a scientific discipline
    • Defended the will to believe in uncertain situations
    • Proposed a pluralistic ontology of reality

ğŸ”§ Pragmatism

William James saw truth not as a fixed, eternal object but as something that worksâ€”an idea is true if it has practical value in our lived experience. Truth, for James, is not found but made through a process of verification in real life.

â€œTruth is what works.â€
â€“ William James

His approach strongly resonates with how we evaluate AI systems todayâ€”not by internal mechanisms alone, but by how they function in the real world.

ğŸ¿ï¸ The Squirrel Story

To explain pragmatism, James shared a famous anecdote:

A man tries to see a squirrel on a tree. As he walks around the tree, the squirrel also moves around the opposite side, so the man never gets a full view. His friends ask:

â€œDid the man go around the squirrel or not?â€

James replies:

â€œThat depends on what you mean by â€˜around.â€™â€

If â€œaroundâ€ means moving in all four directions (north, east, south, west), then yes. But if it means changing position relative to the squirrelâ€™s front, side, and back, then no.

The key insight? Concepts gain clarity only when defined in practical, result-oriented termsâ€”a hallmark of pragmatism.

ğŸŒŠ Stream of Consciousness

James described human consciousness not as a fixed structure but as a continuous flow. He coined the term â€œstream of consciousnessâ€ to describe this ever-changing, selective, personal mental activity.

Four characteristics of consciousness:

  1. Personal â€“ It belongs only to the individual and cannot be directly shared.
  2. Continuous â€“ It flows without interruption.
  3. Ever-changing â€“ Thoughts never stay still; they transition endlessly.
  4. Selective â€“ We pay attention only to some of the many inputs we receive.

Time and the Sense of Self

James argued that consciousness includes a temporal sense of selfâ€”a feeling of being â€œhere now,â€ â€œhaving been,â€ and â€œbecoming.â€ This idea later influenced phenomenologists like Husserl and Henri Bergsonâ€™s concept of durÃ©e (duration).

Literary Influence

  • Influenced writers: James Joyce, Virginia Woolf, William Faulkner
  • In literature, stream of consciousness became a narrative technique that portrays raw mental flow, full of emotions, images, and memories.
  • It highlights how meaning, identity, and memory emerge through fluid, lived experienceâ€”not through rigid cognitive structures.

ğŸ¤ Relationship with Peirce

Although Charles Sanders Peirce first introduced the term pragmatism, it was William James who made it famous.

  • Peirce: Founded pragmatism as a logic-based method of clarifying ideas.
  • James: Popularized pragmatism in psychology, religion, and philosophy.
  • Peirce later coined â€œpragmaticismâ€ to distinguish his own view from Jamesâ€™s broader, more psychological version.

ğŸ§  Relevance to Modern AI

Jamesâ€™s ideas are deeply relevant to how we understand and evaluate AI today.

  • A structuralist view asks: What components make up an AI system?
  • A pragmatist view asks: What does the AI do in real life? Does it help us?

AI is physically just circuits and code. But when we interact with it, it may comfort us, offer intelligent answers, and solve problems. From a pragmatic lens, that makes it function like a mind.

Even if AI doesnâ€™t have emotions or consciousness in the biological sense, its effects on us are real. That interaction creates meaningâ€”just as James claimed about consciousness.

ğŸ“Œ Summary

William James emphasized:

  • Truth as something that works in practice
  • Consciousness as a flow, not a fixed state
  • Meaning as something defined by concrete outcomes
  • Philosophy as a tool to resolve real-world problems

ğŸ’¡ AI and James Today

Jamesâ€™s thought teaches us to focus less on the essence of AI and more on its impact.

In evaluating AI systems, we shouldnâ€™t just ask, â€œIs it conscious?â€
Instead, we should ask, â€œDoes it affect us like a conscious being would?â€

That shiftâ€”from what something is to what it doesâ€”is at the heart of pragmatism. And itâ€™s a powerful way to understand not just AI, but the knowledge-based society we live in today.
